thread.title: No job, no worries: Migrants mentored on how to start their own businesses
thread.title_full: No job, no worries: Migrants mentored on how to start their own businesses

author: Barbara Miller
title: No job, no worries: Migrants mentored on how to start their own businesses
text:
Map: Sydney 2000 
Instead of scouring job ads and signing up for endless interviews, a new program is coaching migrants to start their own businesses. 
The Catalysr initiative is the brainchild of two Sydneysiders, Jake Muller and Usman Iftikhar, and aims to tackle unemployment in Australia's migrant community. 
"Statistics show that 60 to 65 per cent of the people who come to Australia as either refugees or migrants are either unemployed or underemployed, so they are not working in their industry," Mr Iftikhar told Lateline. 
The venture is partly driven by Mr Iftikhar's own experience trying to find work in his field of engineering when he first arrived in Australia from Pakistan. 
"I thought it was just me," he said. 
"But then once I did the research and I found there are a lot of cultural barriers, like we don't really know how the market operates there, or network barriers." 
Around 20 migrants are taking part in the four-month Catalysr course in Sydney. 
Of the start-up ideas being worked on at the course, one is an app that allows business owners to send real-time offers to customers in their proximity, and another is a driving test simulator that uses Google Maps. Photo: Jake Muller and Usman Iftikhar, the founders of Catalysr. (ABC: Barbara Miller) 
Aneela Younis, a former telco manager from Pakistan, is also a participant, hoping to bring Pakistani street food to Australia. 
Ms Younis had a comfortable life at home in Lahore; a good job, domestic help, and family at hand to help care for the couple's young daughter. 
When she finally resettled in Australia 18 months ago, she struggled to find work in her field. 
"The most common question I got was 'do you have local experience?'" she said. 
"Unfortunately I don't have local experience and it took me a long time to get into the job market and still I couldn't find the job that I am looking for, as I was in upper management over there but I have to start here from the entry level." 
She and her husband are now refining what may soon be their business product, in their kitchen at Homebush. 
The dish is called Anda; a Pakistani egg burger that consists of a soft patty in a bun, covered in sauce and topped with a spicy omelette. 
"I'm a little bit anxious at how the people are going to like it, whether they are going to like the taste," she said. 
"So that fear factor is there, but still we are positive." 
Mr Iftikhar said Catalysr participants had now started road-testing their ideas and refining their business models. 
"One of the things that we are trying to instil in their minds is that they should be trying to solve a problem, rather than just going out and creating something and finding out that no-one needs it," he said. 
Watch the story tonight on Lateline at 9.30pm (AEDT) on ABC News 24 or 10.30pm on ABC TV.
